intro: Brassica oleracea subsp. gongylodes, commonly known as Chinese broccoli, is a leafy vegetable characterized by its thick, edible stems and large, cabbage-like leaves. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is native to East Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a compact rosette of dark green, fleshy leaves. Its stems are swollen and can be harvested before flowering, making it a versatile crop for both culinary and nutritional purposes. The plant prefers cool climates and well-drained soil, and it is rich in vitamins A, C, and K.
